senses.sense: Synonym of papaveraldine
(chemistry) The amide of xanthic acid.
(carbohydrate) A polysaccharide, consisting of galactose and mannose residues, produced by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris
Archaic form of xanthan.
plural of xanthan
(chemistry) Any salt or ester of xanthic acid.
plural of xanthate
(chemistry) Conversion into a xanthate.
(chemistry) The water-soluble part of the yellow carotenoid pigment present in the cell sap of some plants.
plural of xanthein
A deposit of cholesterol on the eyelid.
Exhibiting or relating to xanthelasma.
a disease resembling xanthelasma, which leaves yellowish or brownish patches on the skin
(organic compound) any of a group of tricyclic heterocycles (dibenzopyrans) that are the basis for a range of dyes such as fluorescein and eosin
plural of xanthene
Of a yellowish colour.
(zoology) Any crab in the Xanthidae.
A compound of xanthogen.
(dated, organic chemistry) Any derivative of xanthogen
Alternative spelling of xanthine
(chemistry) Any of a group of alkaloids that include caffeine, theophylline, and theobromine as well as the parent compound, a precursor of uric acid found in many organs of the body.
plural of xanthine
plural of xanthin
An abnormally high level of xanthine in one's urine.
The genetic disorder that causes this excess.
(organic compound) The thione analog of xanthine, 9H-xanthene-9-thione
(biology, zoology) A yellowish colouring of pigments in hair, skin, feathers, etc.
A variety of vesuvianite found in limestone near Amity, New York.
Dated form of xanthinuria.
(botany) Having yellow fruits.
Alternative letter-case form of Xanthochroi
(pathology) A condition characterized by yellow patches on the skin
pertaining to people or races with light hair and pale complexions
(anthropology) Pertaining to the Xanthochroi; having fair hair and a pale complexion.
(anthropology) A member of the Xanthochroi.
Alternative form of xanthochromism
(medicine) The yellowish appearance of cerebrospinal fluid that accompanies certain conditions, especially subarachnoid hemorrhage.
Having a yellow colour
Yellow‚Äêskinned; of or pertaining to Xanthochroi.
(chemistry, obsolete) Derived from or containing xanthocobalt.
Synonym of xanthoconite
(mineral) A mineral containing silver, arsenic, and sulphur.
The organic compound with chemical formula C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>10</sub>N<sub>4</sub>O, related to creatinine.
color blindness in which red and green cannot be distinguished
A form of color blindness in which red cannot be distinguished from green, but only blue from yellow.
One who is afflicted by xanthoderma.
A yellow coloration of the skin.
(rare, formal or humorous) A person who has yellow teeth.
(rare) Having yellow teeth.
(chemistry, dated) Formerly, a hypothetical radical supposed to be characteristic of xanthic acid.
(chemistry) Synonym of xanthamide
xanthate
Producing a yellow colour
(organic chemistry) xanthic
A leucophore arising from a xanthophore.
(medicine) A small, yellow nodule, rich in cholesterol and other lipids, that occurs in the skin, often near a joint
plural of xanthoma
plural of xanthoma
(medicine) A disorder in which excess lipid accumulates in the body and produces xanthomas
Of or relating to xanthoma or xanthomatosis.
(anthropology, dated) Having yellow, brown, or olive skin and black hair.
A graduated scale of colors from blue to yellow, white, or green, for determining the color of ocean or lake water.
(pathology, oncology) A lipid-filled myeloma associated primarily with tendon sheaths.
(organic compound) An aromatic ketone, 9-oxo-xanthene, that is used as an insecticide.
plural of xanthone
(biochemistry) The yellow form of chromophane
(biology) A xanthochrome-containing chromatophore, frequently a lipophore
Dated form of xanthophyll.
(organic chemistry, countable) Any of various hydroxy, carbonyl or carboxylic acid derivatives of carotenes.
(organic compound, uncountable) Lutein.
Of or pertaining to xanthophyll.

(mineral, outdated) A synonym of clintonite. The International Mineralogical Association's Commission on New Minerals, Nomenclature and Classification (CNMNC) recommends using clintonite as a replacement in all cases.
Of or relating to xanthophyll.
A visual disorder in which things appear yellowish.
(organic compound) A bitter principle obtained from the bark of Zanthoxylum clava-herculis.
(organic compound, archaic) A bitter crystalline alkaloid extracted from plants of family Xanthoxylaceae.
Of or pertaining to xanthoproteic acid or xanthoproteins.
A protein formed when xanthoproteic acid contacts epithelial cells, indicative of inadequate safety precautions when handling nitric acid.
Alternative form of xanthoproteic
A visual defect, a form of chromatopsia in which everything appears yellow.
visual yellow; any of a form of visual purple that has been bleached by exposure to light
(archaic, medicine) A condition characterized by the occurrence on the skin of small yellow pustules.
A yellow crystalline solid that occurs mainly in the wings of butterflies and in the urine of mammals, converted by microorganisms into folic acid.
purpuroxanthin
(organic compound) A chemical compound found in buckthorn berries (Rhamnus cathartica).
examples: The aglycone of xanthorhamnin is rhamnetin.

senses.sense: (botany) Any of the genus Xanthorrhoea of grass trees.
(mineral) Synonym of limonite
(pathology) A yellowish discolouration of tissues undergoing degeneration.
(alchemy) Synonym of citrinitas
(botany) Having yellow seeds
Exhibiting or relating to xanthosis.
Yellow-brown; yolk-colored.
(archaic, ethnology) Pertaining to people with yellowish, red, auburn, or brown hair.
(mineral) A dull brown or yellow triclinic mineral.
(organic compound, obsolete) The active principle of the prickly ash (formerly in genus Xanthoxylum, now Zanthoxylum).
(pathology) Synonym of xanthinuria
(organic compound) An organic compound with chemical formula C<sub>13</sub>H<sub>10</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, used to test the levels of urea in the bloodstream.
(organic chemistry) The univalent radical derived from xanthine.
Archaic form of jerky.
A carved pole erected as a memorial to the dead by some Native Americans of Western North America.
